question: [File: aptos-core/config/src/config/execution_config.rs] [Function: optimize()] [Waypoint Constant Hardcoding] Are the hardcoded MAINNET_GENESIS_WAYPOINT and TESTNET_GENESIS_WAYPOINT constants verified against actual network state, or can they become stale/incorrect after network upgrades causing bootstrap failures? (High)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/execution_config.rs] [Function: optimize()] [Local Config Override] Does the check for local_execution_config_yaml['genesis_waypoint'].is_null() properly handle all YAML null representations, or can attackers use alternative null encodings to bypass the override prevention? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/execution_config.rs] [Function: optimize()] [Version Check Bypass] Can an attacker set base.waypoint.version() to exactly GENESIS_VERSION (0) to prevent automatic waypoint injection, then later modify it to participate in consensus with incorrect genesis state? (High)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/execution_config.rs] [Function: optimize()] [Panic in Production] The Waypoint::from_str() call uses panic! on invalid genesis waypoint strings - can this be triggered in production environments causing validator crashes? (High)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/execution_config.rs] [Function: optimize()] [Race Condition on Modification] If multiple threads call optimize() concurrently on the same NodeConfig, can race conditions lead to inconsistent genesis_waypoint values or lost modifications? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/execution_config.rs] [Function: optimize()] [Return Value Confusion] Does calling code properly handle the Ok(true) vs Ok(false) return values to detect config modifications, or can silent failures in optimization go unnoticed? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/execution_config.rs] [Field: concurrency_level] [Integer Overflow] Can an attacker set concurrency_level to u16::MAX (65535) to allocate excessive thread pools causing memory exhaustion and validator crashes? (High)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/execution_config.rs] [Field: concurrency_level] [Zero Concurrency Attack] If concurrency_level is set to 0 (supposed to use default), does the fallback calculation handle edge cases like num_cores=0 or can it result in zero actual concurrency causing transaction processing deadlock? (High)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/execution_config.rs] [Field: concurrency_level] [Resource Starvation] Can a malicious validator intentionally set concurrency_level=1 to severely bottleneck transaction execution while still appearing online, degrading network performance? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/execution_config.rs] [Field: concurrency_level] [DEFAULT_EXECUTION_CONCURRENCY_LEVEL] Is the constant value of 32 appropriate for all hardware configurations, or can attackers exploit validators with fewer cores to exhaust CPU resources with the default setting? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/execution_config.rs] [Field: num_proof_reading_threads] [Thread Exhaustion] Can setting num_proof_reading_threads to u16::MAX cause thread pool exhaustion separate from concurrency_level, creating proof reading bottlenecks? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/execution_config.rs] [Field: concurrency_level] [Consensus Manipulation] Can Byzantine validators coordinate to use different concurrency_level values to create subtle timing differences in transaction execution, potentially breaking determinism? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/execution_config.rs] [Field: paranoid_type_verification] [Safety Bypass] If paranoid_type_verification is disabled, can attackers craft Move transactions that violate type safety invariants (e.g., treat u64 as address) to corrupt blockchain state or steal funds? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/execution_config.rs] [Field: paranoid_hot_potato_verification] [Hot Potato Exploit] Without paranoid_hot_potato_verification, can malicious Move code duplicate or destroy hot potato values improperly, breaking linear type guarantees and causing state inconsistencies? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/execution_config.rs] [Field: paranoid_type_verification] [Performance Attack] Can an attacker craft transactions with deeply nested type structures that, when paranoid_type_verification is enabled, cause exponential verification time leading to validator DoS? (High)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/execution_config.rs] [Field: paranoid_hot_potato_verification] [Resource Leak] If hot potato verification fails during transaction execution, does the system properly rollback all state changes, or can partial application of hot potato operations corrupt resource accounting? (High)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/execution_config.rs] [Field: async_runtime_checks] [Race Condition in Checks] When async_runtime_checks is enabled and paranoid checks run in parallel during post-commit hook, can race conditions cause check results to be ignored or applied to wrong transactions? (High)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/execution_config.rs] [Field: async_runtime_checks] [Check Bypass] If paranoid checks are performed asynchronously after commit, can a validator commit invalid transactions before async checks detect violations, causing irrecoverable state corruption? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/execution_config.rs] [Field: blockstm_v2_enabled] [Version Mismatch Attack] Can validators run with different blockstm_v2_enabled settings (some v1, some v2) causing divergent transaction execution results and chain splits? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/execution_config.rs] [Field: blockstm_v2_enabled] [Parallel Execution Bugs] If blockstm_v2_enabled introduces new concurrency bugs, can attackers trigger race conditions in BlockSTM v2 that don't exist in v1, causing non-deterministic execution? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/execution_config.rs] [Field: blockstm_v2_enabled] [Rollback Attack] Can the transition between BlockSTM v1 and v2 be exploited by attackers to cause incorrect rollback of speculative execution, leading to transaction replay or double-spending? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/execution_config.rs] [Field: blockstm_v2_enabled] [Performance Degradation] Can an attacker craft transaction patterns that specifically exploit performance issues in BlockSTM v2 (when enabled) to slow down block execution and harm network liveness? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/execution_config.rs] [Field: layout_caches_enabled] [Cache Poisoning] If layout_caches_enabled is true, can an attacker inject malicious Move type layouts into the cache causing all subsequent transactions using those types to execute incorrectly? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/execution_config.rs] [Field: layout_caches_enabled] [Cache Invalidation Failure] When layout_caches_enabled, does the cache properly invalidate entries on Move module upgrades, or can stale cached layouts cause transactions to execute with outdated type information? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/execution_config.rs] [Field: layout_caches_enabled] [Memory Exhaustion] Can an attacker create thousands of unique Move types to fill the layout cache when layout_caches_enabled=true, causing memory exhaustion and validator crashes? (High)
